718803f-a.text:
(1)
173, 171, 169 Christopher Street, north side, between West and Washington Streets. No. 171 is the one-story frame shed in the center
of the picture.
In front of No. 173 stands the New York Publio Library's Circulation Department truck, which travels about the Bronx.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, three years later. The frame shed has been faced with tin; and the Volmer automobile agenoy has moved away from
No. 169.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 115.

724716f-a.text:
West Street, west side, north from and including the ferries at Pier 44, North River, opposite Christopher Street. This view was taken the year before the building of the first section of
the West Side Elevated Highway.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
724716f-a.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724721f-a.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724722f-b.text:
(1)
West Street, center and east side, from Christopher Street to West 10th (formerly Amos) Street, opposite Piers 44 to 45, North River, and eaat on the north side of Christopher Street towards Greenwich Street. The spines in the background are those of St. Veronica's
Roman Catholic Church at 153-139 Christopher Street.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A portion of the same, showing prominently Nos. 391 to 393 (right to left). No. 388, the 3-story brick, corner building and the adjoining 27structure have been demolished in this view. This row of buildings replaced the Weehawken Market that was built here about 1830 on a portion of the New York State Prison site. Weehawken Street (shown across vacant
lot) was cut through at tht time.
About 1937.
Hift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.
Nieg ~1942

724322f-a.text:
Weehawken Street, west side, between Christopher and West 10th Street, showing the rear of the building bearing No. 393 West Street. This is popularly supposed to be the oldest structure in Manhattan. It rests on the site of the Weehawken Market, and which in turn succeeded to a portion of the old State Prison of 1797-1829. For further information, see, the New York Times of, Sunday, August 22, 1937. a/co : V.yf.we N2(~ 7e. 1P, 1 720
About 1939
Alexandcr Alland, photo
724322f-a.folder: Weehawken Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724710f-a.text:
West Street, east side, south from Barrow to Morton St's., showing the block extending to Washington St. more or less cleared. Aoross the New York Central Railroad elevated roadbed (west side) appear loft structures on the east side of Washington Street. The 8 story building, No. 517-31 Washington St., is occupied by Bellas, Hess & Co. This utilizes the entire frontage from Barrow to Morton St's. At the S.E. corner of the latter thoroughfare, is the 9 story loft, No. 611-15 Washington St. identified with the Medical Supply Dept. of the
U. S. Army.
724710f-a.folder: West Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724321f-c.text:
(1)
Weehawken Street, west side, from Christopher to 10th Streets. The view also shows the corner building north side of Christopher
Street, from Weehawken to West Streets.
May 12, 1927.

(2)
The same, two years later.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A similar view at a later dat0, showing demolition of Nos. 388 (corner building) and 390 (old 27story building, adjoining) West Street. Shown in a state of collapse is No. 391 West Street.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

724719f-a.text:
(1)
West Street, east side, north from Christopher Street, showing a clearance (N.E. corner), where Nos. 388 and 390 West Street stood. The old 2 1/2-story building,shown in a state of collapse, is No. 391. On the right appears the east side of Weehawken Street, between Christopher and West 10th Streets.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A limited view, showing a closer view of No. 391. A similar
building (frame) just north, is No. 393.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as view No. 1, showing however, a more extensive view of the north side of Christopher Street (right), east from West Street, across Weehawken Street.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
